reviewText:
Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!


A note before I begin: after I played D4 for review I had a few friends over to take it for a spin. One sat in rapt attention, absolutely needing to know how this weird story plays out. One spent most of it drinking and facepalming. These are the two most common reactions to SWERY.


Memory is a curious thing, isn't it? Curiouser still how we ‚Äústore‚Äù them... sometimes memories stay fresh, instantly recallable despite having occurred in the forever rose-tinted, nebulous past. Memories can be locked away, buried just beneath the surface until you find the right ‚Äúkey;‚Äù a weathered photograph, the smell of an old coat, or the splash of rain on your face in the right place at the right time. Sometimes memories are forever locked away, and you'll always find yourself chasing that key.


Did you know that every time you recall a memory you're just remembering your last memory OF the memory? And like all things it fades and melds and changes until it's unrecognizable?


Do you know about string theory? Quantum gravity? Me neither. But I know many lemur species are matriarchal.

ANYHOO.

D4 was cultivated and harvested from the wacky mind-fields of SWERY, the same gentleman who brought us that wonderfully weird love letter to Twin Peaks - Deadly Premonitions.

And boy was the harvest bountiful.

You play the part of one David Young: Bostonian, tequila enthusiast, semi-successful husband and police officer in the narcotics unit. And like all good video game heroes his wife was murdered (semi-successful!), the trauma leaving him amnesic but with a peculiar gift ‚Äì the ability to traverse (seemingly) time and space using mementos with incredibly strong ties to specific events. His mission in life now is to solve his wife's murder, prompted by her final words: ‚ÄúLook for D.‚Äù

A little forward for my tastes but fine, I'll bite.


Confused? That's okay! That's normal. I don't think anyone completely understands these surreal romps except SWERY... possibly. And if anyone says otherwise they are God damned liars. But despite that you'll find yourself riveted. The characters are rich, HILAROUS (intentionally and unintentionally), animated, and strange. The story, as weird as it is, leaves you glued to the edge of your seat. I think I can safely say that this might be one of the most engaging ‚Äúpoint n' click‚Äù adventure games available on the market ‚Äì you can touch everything for points and descriptions, read articles, slap around humans, owls, cats... it's nuts. And the QTE's are some of the most engaging I've ever encountered in a game of this type.

Aesthetically D4 is leagues better than Deadly Premonitions. The music, the voice acting, the charming, cartoony cell-shade art, the ever present creative hand of SWERY, all comes together to make something truly special, perhaps the most memorable and entertaining ‚ÄúTellTale‚Äù style title this year so far. There's a health system (can't take too much damage during fights/interactions) and a stamina system (every action costs stamina ‚Äì grab or purchase food and drinks to avoid passing out). There's even a synchronization system that takes into account actions and dialogue that determines if you're really behaving as David Young would during scenarios. All the while you'll gather credit you can use to purchase outfits, hairstyles, and more (I made my David look like a pirate because I'm a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing adult).

However, there are things to consider before parting with your hard-earned cashola. This is SEASON ONE, two episodes and one prologue, maybe three to five hours of gameplay for the average gamer. And SEASON TWO is dependent on how this game is received, so buyer beware (it also ends on a major cliffhanger). The QTE's I mentioned are weirdly difficult! Maybe it's because they're clever little combinations I've never seen, but you'll be hard-pressed to get a perfect score. Likewise, the synchronization conversations assume you're living inside David (and SWERY's) brain. Sometimes you'll choose a dialogue branch (lacking context, inflection) thinking David would say it and you'd be dead wrong, resulting in a lower synch score. And I think it goes without saying... but I'll say it: this game is not remotely for everyone. If you're a fan of Deadly Premonitions this is absolutely a must buy. If that wasn't your cup of tea you aren't likely to enjoy this. It's a western looking game with very Japanese sensibilities ‚Äì keep that in mind.


And I would be remiss not to mention a certain character's terrible, awful, abysmal voice acting delivery. You'll meet him in Episode 1 (the cinematography of that scene is BRILLIANTLY TERRIFYING).


AND.
HE.
WILL.
E-NUN-CI-ATE.
EVE-RY.
SYL-LAB-LE.


I get it, I do. He's supposed to be like the G-Man from-Half Life in that way I guess. But unlike the G-Man his dialogue may represent a quarter of my initial playthrough. Just a minor gripe. And time theft.


Overall I think this if you're a fan of SWERY, of point n' click adventure types, and of weird narratives you should take the leap, entertain your friends with it for a ‚Äúmovie night.‚Äù It's going to leave a mark on you, that's for sure.

I loved the feel of this game and how it doesn't seem to take itself too seriously. There is so much about it that is just straight up hilarious and I love that. The characters are quirky, the action scenes are amusing,and it has the foundation of an amazing story. I love these types of games where you find clues and collectibles be exploring and you can do random silly things to people and things in your environment.

For me all of those things would make the experience worth $15 that I spent, but I find myself constantly torn on that fact.

My reason I'm so torn is due to the fact that Season One offers no resolution to ANY questions. Personally, season one feels like that intro to a great game and just as it's about to pick up steam and get to the good stuff BAM it's over. It truly stops right before an action scene, leaving you confused as to why there is no episode 3.

Season one just feels like a 5hr or less demo ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• tease for a spectacular game. I would still find the game worth my $15 if I knew there would be more, if I could expect a continuation and explanation for at least SOME of the questions I have. At this moment, however, there is no solid news on if or when D4 will continue.

For that fact alone I want to implore everyone who is interested to support it and speak out on your desire to see more. I admit they went about having an episodic series pretty badly. They should have taken a page out of TTG's book on how they do their seasons. For a game season you want to present the story, present questions, but you also really want to resolve SOME and have what feels like a season conclusion. If you are unsure if you will get a continuation in the future, you'd damn sure want to make it so your customers don't get a lack of a finale for a season. You want people to feel satisfied, but also eager to come back. The current 'ending' to this season may do more harm than good to the series as a whole. As an example, I was so close to just telling people to avoid it til news of a continuation arises, but that very well might spell the series' doom.

All in all, be aware of what you're getting into BUT the experience of playing this, the characters, and the story that's being built is all very much worth $15.

David Young is a private eye from Boston, a man with a tragic past that he's trying to repair. On his journey, two friends help him along the way - Amanda, a mysterious girl that's silent and acts like a cat and Forrest, his former boss from BPD.

Paranoid airplane passengers, avant-garde fashion designers, tall men that talk in slow, thunderous voice that rattle cutlery in a ritualistic manner... The atmosphere easily flows between drama, comedy and thriller (even horror!), drawing you deeper into this bizarre world. Do not expect everything handed on the plate though, the gameworld just exists and invites you to explore it and read about it in scattered newspaper clippings.

Love it. Runs fine. Not great, but fine. I made the mistake of letting it run for a while, resulting in a crash. I had a similar problem with Deadly Premonition, though worse.

Very Swery, which is exactly what I signed up for. There's no telling what will happen next. Though you can bet there will be plenty of breaks for food. This game has an obsession with basic pleasures, like drinking, eating with friends and acting silly. Instead of worrying about your health much, your character is more concerned with drinking coffee or tequila to smooth himself out. And despite his central focus in investigating his wife's murder, he still has other interests, and will take opportunities to bring up hockey or music. He watches cartoons. Makes jokes. Sometimes when he's alone, he remembers how dark his life is. You'd mistake him for a real guy if his accent weren't so ridiculous. Many other games would make him a far bleaker character.

So this guy has the ability to travel through time and space at will, provided he has an item tied to a specific event. It's his special advantage over others, allowing him to solve mysteries that would be impossible otherwise. As a trade-off, his own memories become distorted.

The gameplay is a mix of searching the environment, talking to people and occasionally taking part in bizarre QTE sequences. A lot of collection is involved, including searching your own home each day and carefully going over each new area. The pace is very laid back, especially since you can hop back and forth in time at-will, as well as replay previous chapters with items you find later in time. Backtracking for certain sidequests can be quite clever in its use of time travel.

The main draw here is the story and overall personality of the world. It's a version of America filtered through the beer-goggles of an eccentric Japanese cinephile. Familiar, but weird. It isn't afraid to run with an idea, especially if it's over the top. Yet it still takes itself seriously. I appreciate that kind of thing.

D4: Dark Dreams Don‚Äôt Die is a game with big problems that is all but impossible to dislike.

As David Young, former detective now out to find the culprit behind his wife‚Äôs death, D4 took me on an adventure seemingly designed for one purpose: making an impression. Swery and his team at Access Games developed a rather passionate reputation after their eccentric cult classic Deadly Premonition became a surprise hit, but where DP was overburdened by its mechanics and ambition, the significantly smaller D4 proves a far more suitable conduit for whatever insanity Swery manages to dream up.

D4 falls somewhere between the modern adventure game as told by Telltale, and the QTE heavy efforts of Quantic Dream. Hav ing been originally designed to be played exclusively with Microsoft‚Äôs Kinect, D4 focuses itself around single screens and simple gestures, an interface that at first feels moderately restrictive but ultimately works in the game‚Äôs favor. It‚Äôs always clear where you‚Äôre supposed to look, what you can interact with, and when you‚Äôve missed something important, as well as being generally straight forward and intuitive where a more traditional control scheme may have been overbearing.

What‚Äôs so endearing to me however is in the ways D4 appropriates mechanics from other games that ultimately have no reason to be here. There‚Äôs a stamina bar you refill by picking up food that‚Äôs been for some reason stowed throughout every level, a health bar that takes a slice off when you fail a prompt, and a credit system that rewards you for almost every action you take and can be spent on a rather outrageous number of unlockable costumes. In most games I‚Äôd scoff at how pointless it was to include things like this, but with D4 it becomes part of its personality. There‚Äôs a feeling that Access Games do not completely understand how to make the game they‚Äôre trying to, which leads to them pilfering bits and bobs from other games to fill in the ‚Äúgame-y‚Äù portion of D4, but they display such an infectious enthusiasm in everything they do that I eventually stopped caring about the trivial bits of D4 and in some ways even found them charming.

D4 is so entirely detached from its peers in almost every way, that these little touches mostly amounted to winks and nods at a medium Access Games clearly loves working in, and thankfully never encroach upon anything else in the game. What is left then is a crash course through a world of extremes, from D4‚Äôs over-the-top characters, to its love of ridiculous dance-like fight scenes. D4 is obsessively spectacular, each scene enriched with a playful gravitas that would seem excessive if it wasn‚Äôt for how much more absurd the rest of the game is. D4 made me laugh more than any game I can remember in a long time, and I think it‚Äôs because it always seems in on the joke. It isn‚Äôt necessarily trying for comedy, but it‚Äôs aware of itself in a way most similarly bizarre games completely miss, playing to its strengths and remembering to have fun with itself instead of just the player.

My biggest disappointment with D4 is mostly in how it chooses to portray some of its characters. There‚Äôs the damseling of David‚Äôs wife right from the start, taken a step further by the way D4 infantilizes her at every point. Some characters spout blatantly sexist commentary, and in general the women of D4 end up feeling like they were included mostly to ridicule, injure, or give David someone to fall into a compromising position with. I also found the token person of color to be problematic, as he‚Äôs portrayed as almost alien in his mannerisms and how he shows up inexplicably throughout the game mostly to be unsettlingly weird in a way that isn‚Äôt shared among the other characters. None of this is done in a way that feels intentionally malicious, but they were enough for me to shake my head and wish D4 had done better, because in general it avoids most of the worst ways women and people of color are often displayed in games and at points almost came close to being one of the better instances of representation in games.

D4: Dark Dreams Don‚Äôt Die is an imperfect creation, one that‚Äôs janky, at times conflicted with itself, and which may never be finished (this being only the first season and ending on a huge cliffhanger). But it‚Äôs also one of the most earnest games I‚Äôve ever played, with a passion that shows up in even the endearing ways D4 fails to reach its full potential. It‚Äôs a game that I want to love unconditionally because D4 deserves it. It deserves a shot and a chance to do better, and for whatever faults it may have I feel no hesitation in saying everyone should play it.

On the PC port...
After the mess that was Deadly Premonitions‚Äô PC port, a lot of people are no doubt justifiably concerned as to the technical state of D4. Thankfully, D4 is (mostly) a big improvement. I experienced no crashes or major bugs throughout my playthrough, and using a mouse proved a serviceable stand-in for the Kinect (though some immersion may have been lost in the transition). Optimization isn‚Äôt as lucky, with some shockingly high system requirements that seem to be mostly accurate (I experienced some serious frame-rate drops playing on a machine that hits the minimum requirements and which has managed to run far more intensive games in the past). It never became unplayable due to the lax pace of the game, but for whatever reason speaking to characters caused the frame-rate to drop into the teens where it had previously been smooth. It isn‚Äôt anywhere near the problems Deadly Premonition faced, but if you‚Äôre concerned about whether or not you can run it downloading the demo would definitely be a wise choice.

reviewText:
This is review for a game with criminally low sales.

D4 is a 3D adventure game that hits you with presentation right from the start and never lets you go till the end of the ride. It has cool characters, impressive directing, awesome dialogues, and really funny QTEs.

D4 is a detective story with murders, dangerous drugs, US marshals and undercover agents. One would think that protagonist is a clueless FBI agent working on a regular case, but no:
you are a private investigator, involved in all this mess only for your investigation's sake.

This game takes place in a super eccentric world, but everything feels very natural and you easily accept all the oddities, without noticing them. It takes a special skill to create an odd world which feels as normal as the world you are currently living in.

The best way to play this game ‚Äî beer in one hand, mouse in the other. D4 is fully mouse-driven (or you can use a controller, it‚Äôs your choice, I‚Äôm not judging you), so it feels like classic point‚Äôn‚Äôclicks used to. It‚Äôs all implemented in a very convenient way ‚Äî after a minute or so, you begin to move like a breeze and track items with ease. It is a good transition of classic point‚Äôn‚Äôclick mechanics to a 3D era.

Core gameplay also has a very cool aspect: you have health, stamina and vision points. Health for hazardous actions, Vision for hints and Stamina for interactions with people and objects. So in this game you can literally exhaust yourself by talking to someone or looking at mirror. Because of this, you can‚Äôt just click everything in sight ‚Äî you must mind the state of your character and make your priorities. As for ‚Äúpixel-hunting‚Äù, lots of it has been made dynamic ‚Äî you must spot something not at your own time, but during an interaction, a cutscene, etc, and be rewarded for success, sometimes even with bonus ‚ÄúExtra cases‚Äù ‚Äî a type of side activity that D4 offers.

Graphics and overall visual aesthetics show that not every game with cell-shading should look awkward. You barely notice it.

Music is nice, but nothing you would listen to outside of the game. It really works within the game, though.

The only real problem this game has is right in its name ‚Äî ‚ÄúSeason 1‚Äù. So yes, it is not a full game, it is only the first part. And this is really a plague of this type of distribution: people don‚Äôt want to buy it before it‚Äôs complete, but it won‚Äôt be completed if people don‚Äôt buy it.

On the other hand, we have a game with deep investigations; cool aesthetics; a topic-based dialogue system that actually works; superb presentation and overall design. Made by developers of a Deadly Premonition, with every good part DP had left intact and every bad part tossed away.

If you‚Äôre still reading this, you definitely should try it out. It is super cool even for what it currently has to offer.

reviewText:
D4 is an experience unlike any other that you could have in video games.

Whether that is a good thing, that is for you to decide. A good starting point is did you like Deadly Premoniton? Then you will probably dig this gem. If you didn't? I suggest passing on the game or at least wait til a sale before taking the plunge into the world of David Young, his charming (terrible?) Boston accent, and Flight 117.

D4 is for the most part an interactive comic, you will be spending most of your time talking to characters and doing favors for them while looking for clues and trying to figure out how someone can disappear from a plane in flight. It took me 3 1/2 hours to main line the story, but I skipped quite a bit of optional side quests in favor of seeking out the next story beat. I found the gameplay interesting and incredibly different than anything I have every experienced, and for me that is a huge bonus. I like to play different types of games every now and again to remind myself that we can still experiement in the game industry.

It is a Swery game, which means its incredibly weird, very weird. The story revolves around several mysteries that are connected in various ways, but the shining part of the game is crazy, memorable characters that inhabit the world and whom you will be interacting with. While 3 1/2 hours wasn't enough time (for me) to remember everyones name (a sign to me that I'm really enjoyed the media I am viewing/playing/reading), the characters are highly memorable and I could describe them in full detail as well as describe meaningful moments that they were apart of.

The game does end on a cliff hanger, but the game is set up for sequels/seasons to continue. This might be a turn off for some, I personally don't mind it as long as content doesn't take too long to come out. I enjoyed my time with the game and want to play the game again to find what I missed and just in general, be in the world that Swery has created.

reviewText:
8.5/10
My likes include 100% de Agave tequila. My dislikes are mainly drugs... And chewing gum.

Overview
D4: Dark Dreams Don't Die -Season one- is the first part of a planned episodic adventure games series developed by Access Games in the same vein as Telltale's cinematic titles. D4 is a crazy story filled with wacky characters and ridiculous situations somehow fittingly wrapped into a serious, moody detective crime story.

Story
D4 follows the tale of David Young, middle-aged ex-cop and widower turned private detective in order to find D, a mysterious individual whose only known initial was Little Peggy's (Young's wife) dying breath.

If the plot I described above sounds super clich√©, I can assure you that this is where any parallel resemblances to other detective stories end. David Young has developed a special power that allows him to find the truth about the past through objects he finds. This allows him to manipulate and learn about the past, convinced that his power can bring back his wife if he can find the right clues.

The story manages to remain entertaining in large part due to the extremely strange characters that David encounters, including his gluttonous, Bostonian buddy called Forrest Kaysen and a crazy half-human, half-cat freeloader called Amanda.

Gameplay
The game plays exactly like any other episodic adventure game the likes of Telltale Games' titles but manages to add some variety to the mixture. A huge variety of objects can be inspected, picked up and collected throughout the game and multiple optional character dialogues, mini-games or side quests can be triggered (or missed) at certain times.

You'll spend a lot of time pointing and clicking, dragging and rapidly executing action-driven QTE sequences but it feels natural and is an enjoyable accompaniment to the pace of the game. The only downside to the game is that it is easy to miss certain events or collectibles and, with the game sectionned into only three chapters, it can take some time to progress through previously-played chapters in order to find what you missed.

Visuals
D4: Dark Dreams Don't Die -Season one- has a gritty cell-shaded appearance, leaving many visual imperfections (such as character outlines overlapping each other) that yet somehow appears intentional and could be considered artistic design.

It's definitely not the cleanest cell-shaded art style I've seen, but it certainly has flair of its own and feels appropriate.

Audio
Great audio work all around. Every member of the cast, whether their roles be minor or major, have fully-voiced english dialogue that sound excellent, with David and his sidekick Kaysen having authentic, Bostonian accents to compliment the game's setting. The music is a delightful mix of instrumental pieces clearly inspired from crime TV shows and sci-fi soundtracks.

Technical
The game plays great at all times, has a slew of PC-centric options and I have not encountered any bugs myself.

The TL;DR
D4: Dark Dreams Don't Die -Season one- is a fantastic adventure game that succesfully compounds the surreal and the authentic, comedy and tragedy and packages it in a completely wild adventure where you can struggle to make sense of what is real and what isn't.

Needless to say, I am extremely excited about a follow-up to Season one. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone.  It is played entirely with your mouse (or controller), and is a point-and-click adventure.  This may sound great, but it is quite different than Telltale's offerings in that the choices you make do not impact the story.  Where this game excels is the interesting character designs - everything from how they talk, act, dress, etc.  On top of the interesting characters is a mystery/detective story layered with murder, amnesia, drugs, and all kinds of weird crimes from exsanguinated bodies, bodies with the flesh inside out, drowning without water, etc.

While a single playthrough of the game is pretty short, say 4-5 hours, it is designed for multiple playthroughs and we are waiting to see if Access Games will give us Season Two, although there don't seem to be any promises on that just yet.  With the multiple playthroughs comes a lot of the things you'd expect in a Japanese production: collectibles, costumes, documents to flesh out the story, numerous sidequests, quirky humor, and 78 achievements to keep you busy. In all, after many playthroughs and getting every achievement it took me about 14-15 hours of game time.

Those players that have played Deadly Premonition will notice a lot of easter eggs, and will see that this game is in many ways a spiritual successor to it.  I don't want to give any spoilers, but those of you that enjoyed Deadly Premonition and Spy Fiction will be rewarded, and for me it added to my experience with the game in a good way.

Final thoughts... I'd say barrier to entry is that you have to like point-and-click play style, with an added bonus if you like quirky Japanese productions.  If any of that interests you I suggest you pull the trigger and play this game now!

Where this game excels is the interesting character designs - everything from how they talk, act, dress, etc.  On top of the interesting characters is a mystery/detective story layered with murder, amnesia, drugs, and all kinds of weird crimes from exsanguinated bodies, bodies with the flesh inside out, drowning without water, etc.

While a single playthrough of the game is pretty short, say 4-5 hours, it is designed for multiple playthroughs and we are waiting to see if Access Games will give us Season Two, although there don't seem to be any promises on that just yet.  With the multiple playthroughs comes a lot of the things you'd expect in a Japanese production: collectibles, costumes, documents to flesh out the story, numerous sidequests, quirky humor, and 78 achievements to keep you busy. In all, after many playthroughs and getting every achievement it took me about 14-15 hours of game time.

Those players that have played Deadly Premonition will notice a lot of easter eggs, and will see that this game is in many ways a spiritual successor to it.  I don't want to give any spoilers, but those of you that enjoyed Deadly Premonition and Spy Fiction will be rewarded, and for me it added to my experience with the game in a good way.

Final thoughts... I'd say barrier to entry is that you have to like point-and-click play style, with an added bonus if you like quirky Japanese productions.  If any of that interests you I suggest you pull the trigger and play this game now!

reviewText:
Input options: Controller and Mouse/Keyboard.

-Interesting and strangely alluring story.
The story takes a lot old 80's/90's TV shows to give a pretty unique feel for a videogame. The core IPs it's inspired by are Memento (2000), Quantum Leap (1989) and every 1990's TV show opening you've ever watched, as well as a few other modern movies like Inception and in general the graphic novel genre with a good celshading look.
Of course, whilst it takes inspiration it also has a lot of originality within the framework, it's not a blatant rip like the creator's other games and it shows that he's actually progressed as a creator a lot since then.
Characters feel well developed, especially the main character who has strong emotional moments that are brought out through the gameplay and various flavour text rather than a cutscene. The story introduces curious scenarios that you wish to figure out. Even flavour text and magazine articles you happen across have large place as background to the story though it isn't immediately apparent.
The game has many quirks.

-Genuinely well thought-out Point and Click/QTE fusion of gameplay,
Point and Clicks may put some off, but this game deserves a test spin, as it can actually have legitimate difficulty. Easy comparisons are Heavy Rain, Policenauts, Catherine's social sections. Quick Time Events also take place, and whilst I'm not partial usually these have all the hype of a Platinum Games style QTE, in a quirky and funny kind of way.
The interface takes a lot more from older games such as Policenauts or Snatcher whilst streamlining them to make interacting with the environment not menu-driven. Immersion is earned through miniature interactive segments, and every item you come across has unique properties that run a voice clip explaining the protagonist's thoughts, a readable article or a world building cutscene that will either leave you slightly upset for him or extremely entertained. All of these are obviously optional.

This game is a slow and methodical one for the most part that does encourage the player to think and consider what's going on around them. There's a lot of dicking around to do (in the detective sense and the unnecessary gameplay sense) and depending on how much you like admiring yourself in the mirror you'll blast through the game in 1 hour or 5 hours, with replayability being encouraged.

But suddenly, the game has faster paced QTE sections. These keep you invested, not by assuming you care about your character's welfare, but by layering slapstick humour, one liners and daft arguments over challenging inputs that feel extremely natural to execute once you've got a feel for it. It's a rather insane departure from Deadly Premonition to see unwarrentedly good game design for what was once a KINECT game on the XBone that shockingly translated well to functions on common inputs. The optional outcomes of these events also encourages replaying the game. There's a surprising amount of content for the pricing.

In short: Don't worry, the game's fun. There's a health and stamina meter, as well as Detective Vision" which you probably won't need if you're good at picking out interactables
date: that aren't too hard to juggle but require more attention than MGS3:Snake Eater's stamina for example
recommended: and it's all executed without menus.\n\nI was left with an incredibly good impression and look forward to the currently developing sequel series."

(My first Review!)

Telltale + Deadly Premonition = D4: Dark Dreams Don't Die.

This game is combines Swery's Twin Peaks influenced story telling and character designs with an episodic style of gameplay that Telltale is known for nowadays. However it does differ from other episodic games in that its more linear and does not have consequences" from your choices as other games such as Walking Dead or Life is Strange. Its focus is more on the story line and the quirky world that is D4.

The story follows a former Boston Detective using his strange powers of "diving" into the past to find out who killed his wife. He is aided by his former collegue Kaysen Forrest and Amanda his "cat" along with other characters that he meets on his journey. Although his wife died 2 years ago he never got over her death and often hallucinates memories of her WHICH GIVES ME THE FEELS!!!

The game has a RPG type upgrade mechanic when completing side quests (cases). Your characters can have their looks customised which adds variety to it. Not to mention it improves your stats as well.

Interesting Story
Quirky Characters
Customise Character Looks
Romance/Tragedy feels of protagonist's past
Awesome soundtrack

Cons:

It may never be finished.

TL;DR

Buy this game to save it from extinction and preserve it for future generations of game nerds. ALSO FEELS! (I'm a sucker for love tragedy stories)"

reviewText:
Being a fan of Swery, I'm quite biased towards this game. But even for those who aren't familiar with this video game director, I still wholly reccomend this game.

This experience is split in to two types of gameplay; Exploration, and action scenes.
-Being a port of a kinect game, you aren't given direct control in the exploration sections. You point yourself in a direction, and click on a movement icon to walk to that specific point. It's very intuitive and easy to learn.
But one mechanic mixes up the usual point-and-click formula: A stamina meter. Everything you do, from opening a door, to walking across the room uses a little bit of stamina. Stamina is replenished by eating food you find in the enviroment. It's an interesting inclusion, and subtly adds to the quirky nature of the game.
-The action scenes control quite differently though. Usually, a direction is displayed on screen, and you move your mouse along its path. These scenes are full of energy, and fun to play.

While the game is short, it has tons of replay value, with hundreds of interactable items, each with unique flavor text. Every single action you perform gives you credits, which can be spent on clothing items, music tracks, and more food for your stamina.
-So far the game consists of a prologue and two episodes, each about 30 minutes to an hour depending on how you play.
-It has plenty of sidequests and collectibles to find, to encourage subsequent playthroughs.



But while I love this game to death, I do have a couple complaints about it.

-Sometimes it is unclear on what will progress the story with no point of return.
A couple times I performed an action, without knowing it would continue the story. Because of this, I missed sidequests and items, having to replay the whole episode.

-No chapter select.
Granted, while the epsodes are short, (about the length of a television episode,) it can be annoying having to replay parts you've gone through multiple times to get to a perticular section. Thankfully, you can start a new save with all your collectibles once you complete the game.

-Very short length.
This is probably the biggest issue with this game. It's incredible short. I've gotten about seven hours at the time of writing, after replaying the first two episodes multiple times. Unfortunately, being a stealth release, this game got almost no attention on launch. Since then, it's sold only about 150,000 copies worldwide. We're probably not going to get more episodes, but we'll just have to wait, as Swery is (at the time) facing medical issues.


Despite these issues, this game is probably my favorite game of 2014, as well as the past several years. There is nothing else like it, and any fan of TellTale or David Cage games would feel right at home. It's funny, well written, and full of genuine love for the project. I would reccomend this game at full price.

reviewText:
D4 is one of the strangest games I have played this year, let alone in my entire life. I came into this game without any knowledge of the developer's previous games. I knew only one thing and that it was an adventure game with mystery elements in it which automatically made me sign up for a point and click game. Interestingly enough, it was not initially released for the PC but was rather planned as a Kinect game.

I can safely say after checking out this game, I got immediately curious for the developer's other projects since D4 just breaks the formula for your typical genre. That's not to say good Adventure games are common nowadays (Although I am starting to notice their rebirth despite their outdated mechanics). D4 is a very eccentric game in all shapes and forms and you can notice my hesitation since I am not sure where I start from but I'll jump right into it.

You play as David Young, a detective that can travel through space and time to discover the mystery of his wife's death.... From his bathtub. The setup sounded really serious and that was the reason I actually wanted to play it in the first place. However, it turned out to be one of the most fun rides I have ever witnessed. It's hard to talk about this game without spoiling so if you are curious to find out yourself, stop here.

David Young along with his partner, Forrest solve other cases along with the main case of his wife's death. The last word his wife, peggy, told him was to find D. David, ironically starts finding anyone that has a name starting with a D since that is all he remembers from the incident.

Controls are pretty basic if you are playing it on PC, almost every object is identifiable and can be examined, which leaves a huge room for exploration for fanatics like me. Examining an object earns you credits and with credits you can buy apparel for your characters as well as food. That's right, every action you take here takes a bit out of your stamina and when your Stamina is depleted, it's basically game over. Another bar that you can use is the vision bar which is basically the game's hint system where it shows you your next objective or it can highlight items that you haven't examined yet. The Vision bar is replenished with Alcohol.

A very interesting concept but in my opinion is quite fun and leaves room for more interactions for the player since there is a lot to collect and explore including flashbacks for David in the form of letters from his wife, magazines that have trivia in them, side quests for each character you meet in the season and a huge food list to cover with its own trivia that you get to share with Forrest. The side quests range from mini games to pop quizzes. All in all, I assure you this is one hell of a ride for those that want no more than mindless fun or a mindful if you want to answer those pop quizzes.

D4 is fairly short if it was tackled from point A to B however, the whole purpose about it is to approach it with a curious mind since you are role playing as a detective. Speaking of which, the game rewards you if you stay in character depending on your dialogue options, although you are not forced to remain in character, it is still hilarious to see the reactions of a flight attendant slapping David for him staring at her rack.


All cutscenes are Quick Time Events and I know QTEs are most of the time disengaging and boring most of the time, but not this time since at least it is not a button prompt and David also has a health bar that depletes if you dont follow the QTE accurately. The scenes have things getting out of hand in every way and I suggest you put up a counter to how many times go WTF"

The game is planned to be episodic and only one season is out so far. I loved how every episode actually has an opening just like a TV show and not only that
date: but there is a recap of the previous episode in each one. I suppose the only thing I hate about it is I have to wait for the next season but then again

hoursPlayed: it succeeded enough for another season and I can't wait to review the new one.\n\nhttp://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2015/08/d4-dark-dreams-dont-die-season-one.html"

reviewText:
Mesmerizing, unique, funny, wacky, strange, intriguing, creepy; the game grabs you and swallows you in mere minutes!
The game play ‚Äì i.e. movements and interactions with the d√©cor and such - is perfect. You scroll and move around the screens with both sticks and the game is riddled with QTEs done right; Telltale could REALLY learn a thing or two from this game! I played it with a controller and headphones to fully enjoy the ambiance. I also played using the mouse after finishing the game and the QTEs became a bit more challenging. You save using phones in game. There‚Äôs action phases mixing up rhythm games and QTEs, there‚Äôs even a score screen after you‚Äôve done them! Those unlock several achievements.  There are also very easy mini games, mostly limited to the secondary bonus quests.
There‚Äôs a LOT of stuff to collect ‚Äì badges, envelopes, clothing - hidden around the scenes. They can be laid out in the open or hidden inside furniture you have to open; you‚Äôll sometimes have to squeeze and pull the camera at weird angles to be able to grab them. All the objects you highlight with the cursor pops out several small descriptions, which can be funny or interesting. There are 78 steam achievements, yikes!
The game uses 3 meters: stamina, vision and health. You consume stamina with every interaction with an object or a person and refill it by eating food scattered around.  Vision highlights all the interactive things, it refills with drinks. Hits lower your health and you heal with bandages. If your energy falls to zero you faint but if you need it you can buy food from a special NPC character that follows you in all your scenes and it isn‚Äôt expensive: completing the prologue awarded me with 4.5k credits and refilling half of the energy bar costs 50 credits. Credits are also used to buy bonus stuff, like clothes or music.
The visuals are astounding; the graphic style is similar to comics, with lush colors and a lot of contrast.  Music and sound is also top notch. I didn‚Äôt have any tech problem whatsoever ‚Äì no slowdown at all.
The story is amazingly told, the game constantly alternates wacky humor and dramatic tense tone. The voiceovers are all well played. Story is divided in chapters and after finishing one you get a very detailed score screen. You can replay any one you completed to try and find everything. The main game took me 10 hours.
Once I started the game I couldn‚Äôt put it down until the end, then I immediately replayed the chapters to search for the missing bonus stuff and to enjoy the dialogues and the characters again! It‚Äôs really the best adventure game I ever played, and I played MANY games.  This one is a pure gem and should be in everyone‚Äôs library!

reviewText:
This is one of those games where I don't even know how to describe what happened over the course of playing it.  It certainly does not take itself seriously or limit itself to silly concepts like physical reality.  A series of unexpected and entirely bizarre things happen  over the course of the three chapters making up this game.  Unfortunately, the last chapter ends on a cliff hanger and the story remains incomplete.  It still is worth a look because something this strange deserves to be looked at.

Just to say how something average in this looks like would be to describe how it starts - After a tutorial scene, you wake up in a bath tub, walk out of the bathroom and are attacked by what is either a woman who thinks she is a cat, or your cat who your entirely mad mind decides is a woman.  After fighting off the cat? a portly man arrives and tells you to use your weird power to go back in time and find some info on the guy who may know something about the guy who killed your wife.  He then drinks a bucket of clam chowder, stacks several slices of pizza together, disjoins his jaw and eats them all in three bites.

All of this is played seriously and without an eyebrow being raised by the characters.  It lends to the game's charm alongside the strange cast of characters series of bizarre events you wind up in.

Gameplay is nothing spectacular for an adventure game.  The gameplay is done through dialogues, item searches, quick time events, and mini games.  You have a set amount of endurance which limits the amount of things you can look at and how many times you can speak to people.  There is a highlight hotkey showing all the interactables, but you can only do that so many times before needing coffee.  There is enough food laying around so I never had any problems looking at everything in an area at least once.

Puzzles are served fewer in quantity and in smaller areas than what you may see in other adventure games.  It does set the pacing and focus on one event at a time.  None of the puzzles can be considered particularly difficult, the hardest part may be finding the point on the screen where that one item your looking for is before bringing it back to the character who wants it.  Transitioning to the mini games can be jarring as you don't expect it and they have nowhere near the polish as the core game.

You get currency for doing well, searching out-of-the-way areas, accomplishing goals, doing well at a mini game.  These are then either  wasted on coffee and food so you can inspect more objects or spent on outfits for the characters you can dress them in as you go through the game.  I honestly thought this form of reward was weak and artificially encouraged replayability - when the game stands fine on its own for replayability - and also seemed like the designer wanted to reward the player but didn't quite know what to give them or do with the currency system he made up.

In all, I'd say this is different enough from most other adventure games in sheer weird value to give it a go if you enjoy adventure games in general.

There are plenty of great games that prioritize plot over gameplay, to great effect. That's clearly where this game was headed, but good storytelling needs more than quirkiness. This game looked promising, but the story was ultimately uninspired. Alternate recommendations: if you're looking for something quirky and thoughtful, go for Life is Strange. If you're looking for something quirky and funny, go for Tales from the Borderlands.

The gameplay in D4 isn't spectacular, but definitely could have held up a narrative if the story was worth telling. Most of the time, you're exploring the world in a point-and-click adventure game style. Every time you interact with something or talk to someone, your stamina drops, an mechanic reminiscent of Deadly Premonition's exhausting status management system. It's enough to discourage exploration, which seems backwards for a game about investigation. The revelations" you get for gathering a complete set of clues are pretty bland for a detective game as well.

D4 is a bizarre take on video game storytelling with good art style and an interesting story.  Unfortunately, it‚Äôs hampered by several technical missteps.
Access Games really just wants to tell a story; but it has to be bothered with making something that can be called a game.  This causes D4 to prod you with menial tasks such as moving your mouse sideways to open a door, randomly guessing a password, or collecting magazines for your ‚Äúscrapbook‚Äù.  None of this adds to the experience.  The game doesn‚Äôt know how else to keep the player engaged.  After all, it‚Äôs not a television show.

ProsVery unique / bizarre characters and story
Funny
Good art direction
Superb attention to detail - they bothered to draw little water-spot etchings on the sink mirror!
Overall I think I like the story, I think‚Ä¶..
ConsVery clunky, imprecise, and slow controls
Art style is good, but graphics are sloppy.  So many textures are just blurry pixelated blobs.  No AA or other post-effects.  It's on the Unreal engine so all of these features should be available.
The game is frame locked to 62 FPS but it can be unlocked.  See my guide How to unlock the 62 FPS cap in 2 minutes!
The game is short - a prologue, and two episodes.  I think at least one more episode to call this a season would be sufficient.
The pacing of the game is slow.  It just takes a long time for anything to really happen.

Nonsensical gibberish clothed in the guise of offbeat quirkiness.

It's as if a Mulholland Drive era David Lynch and a bunch of mediocre devs decided to cough up a video game.

reviewText:
Definetely a special one this game. Want a game with unique art, a throwback to the Shenmue 'action' scenes, a hilariously bizar story, a great soundtrack and just an all around good vibe? This might just be the game for you.

Story:
I don't want to spoil the story too much so I'll keep it short. The story is about David Young and his dead wife, Little Penny. You step into David's shoes to go back into the past, to find out who is responsible for his wife's death with only 'Look for D' and his memento powers which allow him to go back in the past as help. You encounter amazing characters and it just gives an all around good feeling at what pace it has.
The bad part is though.... will there be an episode three? Will there be a season two? Episode two ended on a huge cliffhanger which just demands for more episodes / seasons.

Graphics:
Look at the trailers and pictures. This game has an amazing graphical style which adds so much to the game. You want to discover every single detail and the moment the 'action' scenes are going on it's almost a pitty you have to go through them at a decend pace. You don't want it to stop, you want more, more, more,.... That this game is a work of passion is most easily noticed by the art. Kudos to the artists!

Gameplay:
The gameplay of D4:DD is pretty simple, there's the dedective part and there's the 'action' part. The dedective part is straight forward and you're never clueless thanks to the Vision skill you can activate at pretty much every time showing you what you can interact with and where the next pieces of the puzzle are. So pretty straight forward point-and-click. The 'action' scenes are pretty much quick time events. You can use both a controller or a mouse to play the game, I tested both and I preferred the mouse. While they're not hard to complete and not much to it comes to 'gameplay', these scenes are bizare, hilarious and somehow this makes the 'drag from left to the right' events pretty damn fun no mater how simple.

Overal:
+ Great Soundtrack
+ AMAZING art, absolutely breathtaking at times
+ Hilarious and bizare story
+ Brilliant character design

- (so far) short story and it ended on a huge cliffhanger
- Simple gameplay, while this isn't an action game, you just sit around looking at scenes a bit too much

So far I'd say if this is what you are looking for, and you immediately fell in love with the art and humor in this game from the trailer, it is worth its price and you will have a great time. If you're looking for lots of action, the art style isn't your thing, ... don't bother really. Overall, allthough this will definetely be higher if / when new episodes or seasons get released, I will rate this game:

7.5/10

reviewText:
It's a shame this game's future depends on sales.  I would, at this point, rather that SWERY try crowdfunding for the rest of the episodes and see if he can make due on that.

It's also a shame that the ridiculous DLC listed on the store page is likely to turn some people away before they even look at the game.  All of the DLC is pointless, so the game very much stands on its own.

So what is D4?  In short, it is an adventure game in the classic sense.  You point, you click, you solve puzzles... sort of.  Fact of the matter is, it's by SWERY, the gonzo game maker who brought you the wonderfully bizarre Deadly Premonition.  Haven't played that one?  No worries.  He also made Spy Fiction... oh, you haven't played that one, either?  Well, nobody did, so you're not alone.  The point is - it's weird.  Purposefully so.

Like Deadly Premonition, however, the key to all SWERY games are its characters.  As bizarre and twisted as the world is, the characters remain strangely compelling despite their completely bonkers behavior and that is key for holding anyone's interest in an adventure game.  First, the hero is a Boston native and the accent is... well, mostly passable... but moreover, he's an ex-cop-turned-PI with a murdered wife and he can travel through time... or can he?  Then there's the pet cat, who is also a slim blonde woman in a onesy, who is also a shop.  No, I'm not kidding.  And then there's his buddy - the actual cop - who can eat four hotdogs at the same time without chewing, has a bum leg, and hangs out at your place all day because the alternative is going home to his New Yorker wife to argue about sports.  And that's just inside the house.  You have no idea what awaits you once you leave it.

Trying to describe the game is like trying to describe Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.  There's a certain charm to the way it presents itself.  At once it is both familiar and completely outlandish.  The mechanics are adapted from the Kinect, so most of your interaction will be clicking on hotspots and waving/swiping your mouse across your desk when the action sequences come along.  But the meat of the game - hero, David Young is a PI - is investigation.  That ultimately means, like in proper adventure games, going up to people and interrogating them.  For some thematic flavor, the game encourages you to choose the responses that best sync up with what David would actually say vs. what you might say.  It's a neat touch.  But what's outlandish is everything surrounding the mechanics.  From presentation, to the music, to the wacky cast, D4 just goes out of its way to be weird in a charming way.

Granted, this game isn't for everyone - if you gave Deadly Premonition a go and didn't like it, you're not going to find this your cuppa, either.  If you didn't... well, I might just recommend it over this if only because D4 is an incomplete experience.  If you want things to fall into place neatly and knots totally tied and unloose... move along. Definetely a special one this game. Want a game with unique art, a throwback to the Shenmue 'action' scenes, a hilariously bizar story, a great soundtrack and just an all around good vibe? This might just be the game for you.

Story:
I don't want to spoil the story too much so I'll keep it short. The story is about David Young and his dead wife, Little Penny. You step into David's shoes to go back into the past, to find out who is responsible for his wife's death with only 'Look for D' and his memento powers which allow him to go back in the past as help. You encounter amazing characters and it just gives an all around good feeling at what pace it has.
The bad part is though.... will there be an episode three? Will there be a season two? Episode two ended on a huge cliffhanger which just demands for more episodes / seasons.

Graphics:
Look at the trailers and pictures. This game has an amazing graphical style which adds so much to the game. You want to discover every single detail and the moment the 'action' scenes are going on it's almost a pitty you have to go through them at a decend pace. You don't want it to stop, you want more, more, more,.... That this game is a work of passion is most easily noticed by the art. Kudos to the artists!

Gameplay:
The gameplay of D4:DD is pretty simple, there's the dedective part and there's the 'action' part. The dedective part is straight forward and you're never clueless thanks to the Vision skill you can activate at pretty much every time showing you what you can interact with and where the next pieces of the puzzle are. So pretty straight forward point-and-click. The 'action' scenes are pretty much quick time events. You can use both a controller or a mouse to play the game, I tested both and I preferred the mouse. While they're not hard to complete and not much to it comes to 'gameplay', these scenes are bizare, hilarious and somehow this makes the 'drag from left to the right' events pretty damn fun no mater how simple.

Overal:
+ Great Soundtrack
+ AMAZING art, absolutely breathtaking at times
+ Hilarious and bizare story
+ Brilliant character design

- (so far) short story and it ended on a huge cliffhanger
- Simple gameplay, while this isn't an action game, you just sit around looking at scenes a bit too much

So far I'd say if this is what you are looking for, and you immediately fell in love with the art and humor in this game from the trailer, it is worth its price and you will have a great time. If you're looking for lots of action, the art style isn't your thing, ... don't bother really. Overall, allthough this will definetely be higher if / when new episodes or seasons get released, I will rate this game:

7.5/10

This is a port of an Xbox One Kinect title where you would control the game with your hand gestures. The developers didn't bother switching up the control scheme for the port. Instead you move a cursor around, which would have been your hand, to interact with tons of boring items such as food, drinks, magazines and fire extinguishers.

Even though I've listed more cons than pros and even though I pondered uninstalling the game from my hard drive after barely half an hour in, the mystery behind the story kept me going until the end. I recommend ignoring all the useless interactibles because they're only placed there to artificially lengthen the game.

I'm still hoping there will be a season 2 released, because at the end of this game we were still left deep in the dark about what really happened. If so, I'd appreciate if the developers would tone down the distractions so that we can focus more on the narative.

Pros:
- Interesting story
- Interesting main character
- Conspiracies and intrigue

Cons:
- QTEs for simple tasks like opening a door
- Too many useless interactive items scattered around
- Too many collectibles floating around which break immersion
- You have to hold the hand cursor over an object to get observations about it until a checkmark appears
- Some characters are way too over-the-top goint straight to borderline annoying
- Too short and ends with a cliffhanger
